body_text.text: Economic opportunities in China are a major "pull" factor stimulating migration, and one major economic effect of migration is to provide a large labor pool to productive activities in urban areas.
body_text.section: Economic factors and migration paths in China

body_text.text: Indeed, highly urbanized provinces with high GDP per capita also have high proportions of migrants ( Figure 1) , with economic opportunities clearly directing migration into certain provinces from others.
body_text.section: Economic factors and migration paths in China

BIBREF0.title: Characteristics of China's urbanization, regional differences and influencing factors

BIBREF1.title: The spatio-temporal distribution of floating population and its development tendency in China. China Population, Resources and Development

BIBREF2.title: China International Urbanization Development Strategy Research Committee. The report on the current status of urbanization rate of China

BIBREF3.title: China 1990-2010 satellite remote sensing mapping of urban expansion

FIGREF0.text: shows the top 50 cross-province migration paths for 5-year periods over the past two decades. The rates of urbanization in the north and east have exceeded those in the south and west, respectively. 1 The cities consistently receiving the greatest number of in-migrants are Shenzhen, Beijing, Guangzhou and Shanghai, and in fact most east coast cities have experienced large numbers of inmigrants. Among provinces, Guangdong has been a major destination historically while provinces like Yunnan in southwest China have become increasingly important destinations for migrants. Geographic accessibility and cultural relationships have also played a role: Sichuan, Hubei, Hunan and Henan are the major origin provinces of migrants to Guangdong, while neighboring Anhui is the major origin province for migrants to Jiangsu (Figure 2). Projections indicate that a large wave of migration and urbanization can be expected yet again in northeastern China, accompanying major industrial development in this region. The relationship between per capita GDP and urban population share in each province or province-level municipality in 2005-2006. The bubble size repsents the percentage of the province's population whose registered residence (hukou) is not the same location as their current residence. Data from National Bureau of Statistics of China 3 and China International Urbanization Development Strategy Research Committee. Top 50 cross-provincial population migration paths in China, based on population censes in 1990 and 2000, and the 1% population sampling survey in 1985, 1995 and 2005. 3 Background shading represents the total immigration to each province during the interval. Path colors indicate the total number of cross-provincial migrants moving between provinces in direction of arrow during the time period. The paths shown accounted for 31%, 50%, 66% and 67% of the total migration that occurred in the four time periods, respectively. Data from Wang, Li et al. 2011.
